question: Your Honor, since Rockwell Corp. began construction, the surrounding residential neighborhood has been enshrouded in a cloud of foul-smelling, germ-carrying, pestilent dust. My client is being forced to breathe known carcinogens daily! Other residents are coming forth on a daily basis to add their voices of outrage!
answer: Your Honor, I submit there were no complaints until Counselor began knocking on doors, drumming up business. And the dust, which Counselor refers to, has appeared on only three occasions. Each time it has been examined and the results... Limestone. Messy, but innocuous.

question: Innocuous?
answer: Defined by Webster's as harmless.

question: I know what it means. Your Honor, imagine how the children in this neighborhood have been made to feel. The pounding of construction ringing in their ears as this skyscraper, a tribute to mankind's greed, grows daily, casting an ominous shadow over their lives, filling them with dread even as they are surrounded in a black, toxic fog, blocking out the sun while poisoning their lungs! And Counselor calls it harmless?!
answer: Your Honor, Counselor is attempting to portray my client as a hideous manifestation of evil and corruption. But nothing could be further from the truth. Rockwell has generously contributed ten thousand dollars to this neighborhood's schools, clinics and youth centers! Granting a restraining order on the construction site will throw hundreds of Philadelphians out of work, and will lend validation to this contemptible and groundless nuisance suit, which speaks directly to the kind of greed and treachery that today is threatening the very fabric of our society. You.

question: Right. Miller.
answer: Client of yours?

question: Funny. Excuse me..? Sir? Yo!
answer: Sure.

question: Sure.
answer: ... up to Tax, on fourteen, and get right back, I need you.

question: Just the dazzling paralegal I wanted to see.
answer: I know what that means, and the answer is no. I have a class tonight. Exploit someone else. And since you've asked ...

question: Thanks, Kenneth. Your exam!
answer: Thank you. 98. I gotta go...

question: Catch me later, I'll be here. And tell Amy, I love her painting, it's on my wall. Present.
answer: Hello?

question: Hi, Mom. It's me.
answer: Andy! This is a nice surprise. How are you, hon?

question: I'm fine.
answer: What's Dr. Gillman say?

question: Hold on, Mom. There's no way my client will go along with that. Andrew Beckett. Hi, Karen. I'm sorry I interrupted... Gillman says I'm fine. My blood work is excellent. T-cells are up. Just a sec ... Yes, I think that would alleviate most of our concerns. My platelets look good too.
answer: Are you on one of those conference calls? I hate when you put me on hold.

question: Walter.
answer: Are we interrupting, Andy?

question: In a word, Bob...
answer: Charles is right behind me.

question: Whacked with a racquetball. I appreciate your faith in my abilities.
answer: Faith, Andy, is the belief in something for which we have no evidence. It doesn't apply to this situation. Go home. I mean, get back to work.

question: Thanks, Charles.
answer: No sweat, buddy.

question: It's good to be King.
answer: You want to apply the foundation as evenly as you can, Andy. You don't want to look like you've thrown it on with a spoon.

question: Uh huh.
answer: Okay. You try.

question: Chandra? Don't you think this color's a little... orange for me?
answer: Tahitian Bronze works best on lesions.

question: Thanks, Bruno. I've been out of the office four days. I don't want them to think I've been to the beach. Okay. Check this out. Hides everything, right? What do you think?
answer: You know who you look like, Andy? That actor, in that movie. Not the one where he was autistic, the one where he dressed up like a lady on a soap opera...

question: Tootsie!
answer: You want to try Light Egyptian? What?

question: Excuse me a sec...
answer: Just like my cousin Fredo.

question: I think I need to go to the hospital. Thanks, you guys.
answer: Yeah. Thanks, guys.

question: Gillman's out of her office today. I told her to take a day off, and she did, can you believe it? Did you get someone to cover your class?
answer: Don't worry about it. They took blood? A specimen?

question: Aren't you giving an exam?
answer: I said, don't worry about it. You got a fever, baby.

question: I almost didn't make it to the bathroom, Miguel. I almost lost control right in front of everybody.
answer: So what? It's nothing to be ashamed of. You have nothing to be ashamed of, okay?

question: Wait, here's my guy... Hey!
answer: Mr. Beckett, I'm sorry...

question: About my blood work?
answer: We're waiting... ... meanwhile, I'd like to prepare you for a colonoscopy, so we can take a look inside.

question: Shelby? It's me. Jamey's been beeping me, I... Okay, okay, calm down. Put Jamey on.
answer: Andy?! This is a disaster! We can't find your revisions on the Kronos complaint!

question: Slow down, Jamey, for Christ's sake!
answer: I went down to Word Processing to pick up the corrected copy, but they said you haven't delivered the corrections. I told them you've been working on it at home, and...

question: I brought it in last night, around midnight. It's in my computer.
answer: What did you file it under?

question: K-R-O-one. Jamey, I don't have to mention, do I, that we're up against a statute of limitations on this complaint which runs out in... Seventy-five minutes.
answer: It's not here, Andy.

question: You go down to Word Processing and tell those motherfuckers they better come up with that complaint, now! Or they are fucking dead! You tell them that comes from me! Every problem has a solution. Every problem... has... a... solution. Every problem has a solution...
answer: Why are you getting dressed?

question: You're not going to like this. Please try to smile... Thanks for leaving school, and coming here, and... I will be back. An hour, tops.
answer: You're going to the office?!

question: You're not smiling.
answer: You're leaving the hospital? You're going into the office looking like that? Are you insane?

question: One hour!
answer: Drew!

question: Call the messenger service, have someone standing by... Your phone. Think. You brought the discs in, you transferred...
answer: I thought I was supposed to be covering for you. God, Andy, you look awful.

question: Fucking Word Processing lost my Kronos complaint. Which must be filed by fucking five o'clock! If it's late, there's no case... Every problem has a solution.
answer: What can I do?

question: Get down to Word Processing. Help Jamey look. No. No, goddammit! Bob? Something's come up. With Kronos. I don't want to upset Charles, but... Oh, shit, Bob, the complaint's due in forty minutes and I can't find it. No, you don't have to come... Great. Fucking great.
answer: C'mon, Andy, you didn't lose anything... Jesus.

question: I don't know what to do, Bob.
answer: You'll never find it in the dark. What in God's name... ?

question: Bob...
answer: What's wrong with your face?

question: What's wrong with my face? You want to know what's wrong with my face? I've got a skin condition. Next question, Bob? No more questions? Fine. Now can you help me find the complaint?
answer: Allright. Calm down.

question: Sorry...
answer: What was the file name?

question: K-R-O-one.
answer: Maybe you mistyped the name when you were saving it. We'll try combinations of those letters...

question: Thanks, hon. Oh my god... Oh my god... oh my god, look at her... oh my god... Go to Famous Fourth Street and buy a pound of Nova. No! She likes Scotch salmon better. Ah heck, get a pound of both! Get a dozen onion rolls. Get some bagels. Get a dozen. Get a bottle of champagne. Dom Peringon... A hundred bucks a bottle?! Better get a good California... Give me a call. Get everything over here as soon as you can, she's starved. No, not the baby! Lisa! ... Iris, listen How big was this hole you fell into? And this hole was right in the middle of the street? Why didn't you cross at the crosswalk?
answer: Thank you.

question: Explain this to me like I'm a six year old, okay? The entire street is clear except for one small area under construction, with a huge hole that is clearly marked and blocked off, and you decide you must cross the street at this spot. You fall into the hole and you want to sue the city for negligence? ... Of course you have a case! Now, I want you to go with my assistant, Iris, and fill out some forms. She'll tell you about our fee arrangement. Mrs. Finley? Any back pain since the accident? Dizziness? Nightmares? Tell Iris all about it. Take good care of Mrs. Finley, Iris. Beckett, come in. Jesus Christ, what happened to you?
answer: I have AIDS.

question: Whoa-oh! Sorry, I...
answer: It's okay. Can I sit down?

question: Uh, yeah. Go ahead.
answer: New baby?

question: One week old.
answer: Congratulations.

question: Little baby girl.
answer: Kids are great.

question: Thanks, Beckett. I'm real excited about it. What can I do for you?
answer: I was fired by Wyant Wheeler. I plan to bring a wrongful termination suit against Charles Wheeler and his partners.

question: You want to sue Wyant Wheeler Hellerman Tetlow and Brown?
answer: Correct. I'm seeking representation.

question: Continue.
answer: I misplaced an important complaint. That's their story. Want to hear mine?

question: How many lawyers did you go to, before you called me?
answer: Nine.

question: Continue.
answer: I was diagnosed with AIDS eight months ago. During a bout of pneumonia. I recovered quickly and was back at work in ten days. Since I was doing so well on the AZT, we decided against telling anyone about it.

question: We?
answer: My lover and I.

question: Your... lover?
answer: Miguel Alvarez. We've lived together for nine years.

question: Continue.
answer: I dove back into work, everything was fine. Until the lesions started... First on my leg. Then my forearm, my back. Then... my face. For a short period, I avoided the office during the day, waiting for the chemo therapy to clear up the lesions... But I never let anything slide. I made all my calls from home. I worked sixteen hour days on a complaint for a 350 million dollar copyright infringement suit. But the day the complaint was due, it disappeared. Erased from my computer. I thought I was losing it, mentally... That can happen, it's called AIDS dementia when it gets into your brain. But miraculously, a copy of the complaint was located at the last minute, and we got it to court on time... The next morning, I was called to the office for a meeting with the managing partners. Walking down that corridor was strange. Felt like everyone was staring.

question: Hell, they are staring. What's that shit on your face?
answer: Makeup. The partners were waiting for me in the main conference room.

question: Really? Who thinks that, sir?
answer: I do.

question: I had no idea there was a concern in that area. Hey
answer: We've been talking it over, Andy. Your future that is... We feel that, because we respect you so much, we have to be honest with you.

question: Let's put it this way, Andy
answer: In a word, yes.

question: We don't think it's fair to keep you here, where your future is limited. But we wish you luck, Andy, all the luck in the world. And I hate to rush you out of here, but...
answer: But he's got lots of other people's lives to ruin...

question: Who are you?
answer: Okay. Explain to me like I'm a two year old, because there's an element to this I can't get through my thick head

question: The law says people with disabilities cannot be terminated, so long as they can perform the duties required by their position...
answer: Okay, okay... They discover you have this horrible, disgusting, terminal illness, and they panic, for any number of perfectly valid reasons. They're frightened for themselves, their families... Maybe it's the homo angle. Maybe they don't want to rub elbows with someone who's just popped out of the closet with a terminal case of acne. And how do they explain your status to the client for Chrissake?

question: Joe, from the day I arrived to the day they fired me, I performed consistently, thoroughly and with absolute excellence. And if they hadn't fired me, that's what I'd be doing today.
answer: Okay... They want you out. It's against the law to fire you for having AIDS, so they make you look like a fuck up. Which leads us to the mysterious, lost file.

question: They sabotaged me.
answer: I knew you were going to say that. I don't buy it, and I don't see a case.

question: Look. I know I have a case. If you don't want to take it for personal reasons...
answer: Correct. I don't.

question: Thanks for your time.
answer: Beckett? I'm sorry about... what's happened to you. It's a fucking kick in the head.

question: Don't send flowers, Joe. I'm not dead yet.
answer: Find out if Armbruster can see me this afternoon.

question: You had contact with someone who has AIDS, and you're worried.
answer: I'm not worried. What are you doing?

question: Checking your blood pressure, relax.
answer: I didn't have contact. What do you consider "contact?" We were sitting in the same room, three, four feet... What if you shake hands? Wait. I know the answer. Only sex, or sharing needles. I know that. We didn't shake hands, anyway.

question: The HIV virus can only be transmitted through the exchange of bodily fluids, namely blood and semen.
answer: Right.

question: Leave that.
answer: Yeah, but Doc, isn't it true they keep finding out new things about this disease? So you tell me, today, there's no danger, and I go home, and I hold my baby, and six months from now I hear on the news

question: We're going to draw blood.
answer: Why are we going to do that?

question: Joe. I don't care a whit about your private life.
answer: You want to give me an AIDS test?! The guy sat in my office! You can't get AIDS that way, right?

question: Right.
answer: It doesn't travel through the air, by breathing, or touching, right?

question: Not by touching, or shaking hands, or hugging, using the same toilet... Even kissing someone with AIDS is safe. But it there's something in your past you're worried about...
answer: Thanks, Doc, but I don't need an AIDS test. Are you crazy? But thanks for the information. Really. In my past?

question: A homosexual encounter.
answer: Get real.

question: Unprotected sex with a prostitute.
answer: Uh.... No. Not really.

question: You have a problem with gays, Joe.
answer: Not especially.

question: How many gays do you know?
answer: How many do you know?

question: Lots.
answer: Who?

question: Karen Berman. Aunt Teresa. My cousin Tommy who lives in Rochester. Eddie Meyers from the office. Joe Cantwell, he's one of the partners. His lover, Greg. Stanley, the guy who's putting in our kitchen cabinets.
answer: Your Aunt Teresa is gay? That beautiful, sensuous woman is a... lesbian?

question: Duh...
answer: Since when?

question: Probably since she was born.
answer: Allright. I admit it

question: Okay, Joe...
answer: I mean, two guys, doing the horizontal thing? I don't get it. Don't they get confused? "Is that mine? I thought it was yours." Hey, call me old fashioned, call me conservative... I think maybe you have to be a man to get just how nauseating the whole basic idea really is.

question: Fine, Joe.
answer: And the way they work out, pumping up, so they can be macho and faggot at the same time... I can't stand that shit. Now I'm being totally honest with you.

question: That's perfectly clear.
answer: Would you take a client if you were constantly thinking Shit...

question: Would you take a client if you were constantly thinking Shit...
answer: Thank you. I'm fine, thanks. No. But would it make you more comfortable?

question: Oh, Beckett. How's it goin'?
answer: Fine.

question: Who'd you get?
answer: What?

question: Find a lawyer?
answer: I'm a lawyer. How's your baby?

question: Huh? Oh. Great. She's great.
answer: What's her name?

question: Rayisha.
answer: Rayisha. Very nice.

question: How did they find out?
answer: One of the partners spotted a lesion on my forehead.

question: Uh huh... How do you get from one lawyer spotting a lesion, which could have been a bruise, to the partners deducing you had AIDS and basing a decision to terminate you on that conclusion?
answer: Good point. The partner who spotted the lesion, Walter Kenton, used to work for Benton, Myers, in D.C. There's a paralegal there, Maria Torres. She's had lesions on and off for three years. She says it was common knowledge around the office that her lesions were caused by AIDS.

question: They didn't fire her?
answer: No. They didn't fire her.

question: So Kenton connected the... lesion, and whatever suspicions he had about your personal life... to this woman, Maria... and blew the whistle on you. Suddenly you're losing files, and it's time to let you go. But, up to this point, you've been their Golden Boy, their rising star... Their behavior is... inconsistent.
answer: Thank you.

question: There is no relevant precedent.
answer: Arline decision. Supreme Court.

question: Arline? "The Federal Vocational Rehabilitation Act of 1973 prohibits discrimination..." "... against otherwise qualified handicapped persons who are able to perform the duties required by their employment..." "Although the ruling did not address the specific issue of HIV and AIDS discrimination..."
answer: "Subsequent decisions have held that AIDS is protected as a handicap under law, not only because of the physical limitations it imposes..." "But because the prejudice surrounding AIDS exacts a social death which precedes the actual, physical one..."

question: ... interview every employee, support staff, associates, partners. Did any of them know Andy was sick? How did they know? Did he tell them? Did they notice something was wrong with his appearance? None of this information got to the managing partners. We know that. Make sure everyone else does too... And Beckett
answer: Jesus.

question: What about other homosexual facilities, whatever they are?
answer: Charles...

question: What deviant groups or organizations did he secretly belong to? What is it, Bob?!
answer: Let's settle with Andy and put this whole tragic mess behind us.

question: That's kind of... extreme, Walt. Andy's private life is none of our business.
answer: Bob. You're trying my patience. Andrew Beckett is making his private life our business. We gave him Kronos. Did he say, "I'm sick. I might not be able to see this through?"

question: He was doing a great job.
answer: Bob. I must ask you to shut the fuck up. Did Andrew Beckett say "I might not be able to serve our clients to the best of my ability?" He said nothing. And now, Andrew Beckett proposes to haul me into a court of law, to sling accusations at me, in full view of the entire, Philadelphia, judicial establishment. My God.

question: A jury might decide that Andy has a case.
answer: Wait a minute. The man was fired for incompetence, not because he has AIDS. You didn't know he was sick, did you, Bob?

question: Charles Fucking Wyant Wheeler?!
answer: Morning, Filko.

question: You're a Republican, Joe! You belong to the NRA!
answer: How many toilet stalls are there in the women's restroom on this floor, Filko?

question: How many... what?!
answer: Two. How many toilet stalls are there in the men's room? Two, plus four urinals. How many wheelchair accessible toilets in either of those restrooms? Zero. In this entire building? Zero. Get the picture, Filko? Discrimination! You find yourself a female, paraplegic, legal assistant who is qualified to work here, except she can't take a leak... and you've got yourself a sex discrimination suit and a handicapped discrimination suit. Not handicapped. What do you call someone who can't use a normal restroom? "Gastro-intestinally challenged!" Low-life, sleazy scumbags. Of course they want a postponement, I've got a client with a terminal disease. They're going to drag their heels every step of the way, the rotten bastards. (tapping on the window, to the Hey, Beckett. This is Miller. I just wanted to tell you... ... we're trying to set a date for the prelim. Hang in there.

question: I can heal myself. I can heal myself.
answer: I was coming out of the gym today, and I ran into Jimmy. Do you know what he asked me? "What's it like knowing your boyfriend's going to die?"

question: Jerk... What did you say?
answer: I said, "Everyone's going to die, Jimmy. But Drew's not going to die of AIDS. There's a cure around the corner, and he plans to be around to take advantage of it."

question: You got that right, Mikey... You still believe that, don't you?
answer: Yes. I think it will be a simple solution. They'll put it in a syringe, inject it into your bloodstream. It'll neutralize the virus. It'll revitalize the immune system, and people with AIDS will become healthy again.

question: Thank you. We're very happy. Attorney for the plaintiff?
answer: Joseph Miller, Your Honor. Macready and Shilts Legal Services.

question: I've seen your television commercials. "If you or anyone you know has been injured through the fault of others... It should say, "through the negligence of others."
answer: I'll take that under consideration, Your Honor.

question: Fine. I've asked the litigants to be present for this conference, in the hope we can settle this matter today, among ourselves... There is nothing I hate more, than to see lawyers suing each other. If you look at the opinion polls, when Mr. John Q. Citizen is asked to rank professions according to the respect he holds for them... Where are the lawyers? Somewhere below personal fitness trainers and only slightly above child pornographers. If we keep suing each other, if we fail to settle the smallest difference among ourselves with mutual respect, if we continue to scrap like bucks in heat, we'll fall lower on that list. And when people lose respect for lawyers, they lose respect for the law. And when this society loses all respect for the law, we'll be murdered in our beds, my friends, our cherished institutions will be burned to the ground and our children and our grandchildren will live like savages.
answer: If it please Your Honor, we hope to settle this matter.

question: By God you will settle it! If you force this case to trial, young man, you'll regret it for the rest of your natural-born days... Now, Joseph. What would you require to settle this matter today?
answer: Reinstatement at full salary. Back pay covering the period of unemployment and...

question: And what will we find in... da duh da duh da duh... the KITCHEN! Hi, Mom. How do you feel on your fortieth anniversary?
answer: Ancient. How do you think I feel? Put that thing down and give me a hug. Andrew, stop! ... He still doesn't listen.

question: Where's Dad?
answer: He's out in his shed showing your uncle his new riding mower.

question: Andrew Beckett represented your company in a lawsuit in 1990, is that correct?
answer: Wyant Wheeler represented us.

question: But, Andrew Beckett was in charge of litigation for the suit.
answer: That's correct.

question: Were you pleased with his work?
answer: We were satisfied.

question: Were you satisfied, or were you pleased?
answer: We were satisfied.

question: Mr. Laird, when I approached you about being a witness at this trial, and you agreed, you gave sworn testimony in a deposition. Is that correct?
answer: That's correct.

question: According to the deposition, you said you were "thrilled, impressed, overwhelmed" by the quality of Andrew Beckett's work. Do you remember saying that?
answer: I may have said something like that. But that's not how I feel at this moment.

question: Okay, Mr. Laird. Explain this to me like I'm a four year old
answer: We won.

question: Did that thrill, impress and overwhelm you?
answer: It satisfied me.

question: It's a long way between being overwhelmed and being satisfied. A cheeseburger may be satisfying whereas caviar and champagne and roast duck and baked Alaska for dessert might be considered overwhelming. Do you agree?
answer: I might.

question: Five months ago you characterized Andrew Beckett as caviar and now you're calling him a cheeseburger. Your standards have shifted a great deal, and I'd like to know why you've changed your mind.
answer: Since that time I've devoted more thought to the subject, and that's how I feel now.

question: And Walter Kenton knew the lesions on your face and arms were caused by AIDS?
answer: Definitely. People were going around, whispering things. I figured I didn't have anything to lose, so I told all the partners.

question: How did Walter Kenton treat you, after you told him you had AIDS?
answer: Every time he came into contact with me, he'd get this look on his face. I called it, the "Oh God" expression. As in "Oh God, here comes that woman with AIDS."

question: Ms. Torres? Have your employers fired you for having AIDS?
answer: No. When I need time off, for medical reasons, we work it out.

question: Sorry.
answer: Ms. Burton. You're black.

question: Is that a question?
answer: No. Have you ever felt discriminated against, at Wyant Wheeler?

question: Yes.
answer: In what way?

question: Well... One time, Mr. Wheeler's secretary, Lydia, told me Mr. Wheeler had a problem with my earrings.
answer: Your earrings?

question: Apparently, Mr. Wheeler felt they were too... "ethnic" is the word she used. She said he would like it if I wore something smaller, less garish, and... more "American."
answer: What did you say?

question: I said my earrings are American. They're African-American.
answer: Thank you. No more questions.

question: Miss Burton? Do you still work at Wyant Wheeler?
answer: Yes.

question: Were you recently promoted?
answer: Yes. I'm now in charge of the paralegal department.

question: How's the trial going? It's a great case. I saw you on television. I'm a law student. At Penn.
answer: Good school. What year?

question: Second.
answer: Great.

question: Would you like to have a drink with me? I just finished a game, I could use a beer. I don't pick up people in drug stores every day.
answer: Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa... do you think... ? You think I'm... ... gay?

question: Aren't you?
answer: What's the matter with you? Do I look gay to you?

question: Do I look gay to you? Relax.
answer: Relax? I ought to kick your faggoty little ass for you!

question: Take it as a compliment. Geesh.
answer: Don't you know this is exactly the kind of bullshit that makes people hate you guys?

question: Fuck you! You want to kick my ass? You want to try? Asshole.
answer: You're the asshole, buddy.

question: Get a life.
answer: But what was it?! What was this guy thinking... ?!

question: But what was it?! What was this guy thinking... ?!
answer: Don't know, Joe.

question: Is there some kind of expression I've picked up from Beckett?! Some kind of fairy attitude I've unconsciously adopted?! Am I walking different?! Some kind of vocal thing?! Have I picked up some kind of homo vibe?!
answer: Have you changed your aftershave?

question: Very funny. I had a box of Pampers under my arm for Chrissake!
answer: Joe?

question: Yeah... ?
answer: Two men making love... ? Now tell me again... why is that disgusting?

question: Lisa, c'mon. One guy sticking his dick in another guy's mouth? It's disgusting.
answer: Okay, so... help me with this one, Joe... Is it disgusting for someone to put his dick into someone's mouth? Or, is it disgusting for someone to take a dick into their mouth?

question: Great, Lisa. Thank you. "But, ultimately, the complaint was found, wasn't it?
answer: Yes. We found a copy. It been incorrectly filed... We got it to court on time.

question: Has a file ever disappeared like that before? Vanished into thin air, all of a sudden, only to reappear in the nick of time?
answer: I've never known that to happen before. No.

question: I'll rephrase. Did you have anything to do with this file being... misplaced?
answer: Absolutely not.

question: Are you a homosexual?
answer: What?!

question: And how many weeks at a time would you be out to sea, without stopping at port?
answer: Anywhere from two weeks, to several months.

question: Any women on board?
answer: Not when I was in the Navy.

question: So during those long voyages, months at a time, out to sea, no women in sight, a hundred, hardworking, robust, young men, in the prime of their life, at the peak of their natural appetites, desires, their god- given, hormonal instincts... Anything going on?
answer: Going on... like...?

question: You had one guy "like that?"
answer: Yeah. But we took care of him.

question: How did you do that?
answer: We stuck his head in the latrine, after ten of us had used it.

question: You taught him a lesson.
answer: Yes, we did.

question: I'll withdraw. You were aware, when you worked with Maria Torres, that she had AIDS, correct?
answer: She didn't try to conceal it.

question: So you are aware of the difference between a lesion and a bruise, is that correct?
answer: I know the difference. That doesn't mean I'm always able to recognize the difference.

question: But didn't you avoid contact with Ms. Torres, after you found out she had AIDS? She says you acted repulsed by her and you avoided her, is that correct?
answer: I felt, and still feel, nothing but the deepest sympathy and compassion for people like Maria, who have contracted this terrible disease through no fault of their own.

question: Drew! Are you ready? If we start at eight, we'll be done by twelve. It's not going through.
answer: We'll have to flush it again.

question: Hold still. Shit. The goddamn vein's clotted. We have to go the goddamn hospital, so they can change the goddamn catheter.
answer: I have too much work to do. Skip the treatment.

question: We're not skipping this treatment.
answer: I said, skip it, Michael. It's my treatment.

question: Fuck you.
answer: Fuck you. This shit's probably not doing me any good anyway.

question: That shit's saving your life, you asshole!
answer: What's wrong with you?

question: Close the law book.
answer: I'm not going to close the--

question: CLOSE THE FUCKING LAW BOOK!
answer: ALLRIGHT IT'S CLOSED! Jesus!

question: The least you can do is look at me, while I'm sticking this shit into your arm. Forget the fucking case, one hour a day, and give me a little of your time.
answer: You don't think there's much time left, do you?

question: That's not what I said.
answer: You're scared. You think we're near the end.

question: No.
answer: Maybe I should start making plans, is that what you think? Start planning my memorial service? "Begin to prepare for the inevitable."

question: Maybe you should think about it.
answer: What's that mean?!

question: Maybe you should think about it.
answer: I'm not going to die.

question: That's right. We're on the Positive Plan. You don't have a Fatal Disease, you have Manageable Illness.
answer: You want me to give up? Let this thing turn us into victims?

question: Then, what are we, Drew?! The winners? "Ladies and gentlemen, the first prize of AIDS goes to Andrew Beckett and his lover Miguel..." Excuse me, I'm not your lover. I'm your Care Partner. FUCK!
answer: I'm not ready to die.

question: Do you think I'm ready for it?! I hate this shit. I'm not a fucking martyr! I hate every goddamn part of it! Please don't leave me. I love you so much. Don't die, don't leave me, please...
answer: I am so scared. I am so fucking, incredibly, fucking scared... You know, there's only one thing to do. We have to have a party.

question: Beckett. You seem... better. Energized, more alive...
answer: I had a blood transfusion today. I feel great.

question: I'm a law suit.
answer: Not bad.

question: Get it?
answer: Let's find you a drink. What do you want?

question: Beer. We need to go over your Q and A.
answer: Excuse me, I'm having a goddamn party, is that allright with you?

question: Sure. It's fine.
answer: No, we have to do it. But later, allright?

question: Thank you. You think I'm uncomfortable...
answer: Correct.

question: You're right.
answer: Thank you.

question: Congratulations, Miller. You survived your first gay party intact.
answer: Let me tell you something, okay? When you're brought up, like the rest of us, in a place like where I was brought up, there's not a whole lot of discussion about... homosexuals. As a kid, you're taught right away that queers are weird, queers are funny, they're a danger to kids, they're afraid to fight, and they all want to cop your joint. And that pretty much sums up the general thinking out there, if you want to know the truth.

question: Thank you for sharing that with me, Joe.
answer: Let's review these notes for your testimony. We have a big day on Monday. When you refer to Wheeler, call him Charles, to show how you'd been admitted to the inner circle, you were considered one of them.

question: Uh huh...
answer: Beckett?

question: Charles. Okay. Miller?
answer: What?

question: Do you... pray?
answer: Yeah. Sure. Then we establish how Wheeler's boys recruited you after law school...

question: What have you prayed for?
answer: For a healthy baby. For Lisa to make it through the delivery. For the Phillies to get into the playoffs.

question: There's a possibility I won't be around for the end of this trial.
answer: I've considered that.

question: What happens?
answer: We proceed, representing your estate.

question: I've made provisions in my will for some charities. Miguel will need a lawyer. I know it's not your area...
answer: I know a good probate lawyer.

question: Thanks. Do you like opera?
answer: Opera?

question: Want to hear my favorite aria?
answer: Opera?

question: Andrea Chenier, by Giordano. This is Madeleine. She's telling how, during the French revolution, a mob set fire to her house. Her mother died, saving her. "It was during that sorrow that love came to me! "I am Oblivion! I am Glory! I am Love, Love, Love!"
answer: I think I'll... I told Lisa.

question: Right. I'll look over the Q and A.
answer: You're ready, don't worry. Jesus. Fucking guy...

question: Wyant Wheeler had aggressively recruited me. They were the most prestigious firm in Philadelphia, full of opportunity. And I was impressed by the partners.
answer: Including Charles Wheeler?

question: Particularly, Charles.
answer: What impressed you about him?

question: He was... the kind of person I thought I wanted to be.
answer: What kind of person is that?

question: Possessed of an encyclopedic knowledge of the law. A razor sharp litigator, a genuine leader, gifted at bringing out the very best in others. An awesome ability to illuminate the most complex of legal concepts to colleagues, courtrooms, the person on the street. The kind of person who plays three sets of tennis but doesn't sweat. But underneath the elegant surface, was an adventurous spirit.
answer: Obviously, at this time, you weren't sick.

question: It's possible I was infected with the HIV virus at that time, but I wasn't diagnosed until several years later.
answer: You didn't look then, the way you look now?

question: No. I was thirty pounds heavier. I was athletic.
answer: A regular all-American guy?

question: I suppose you could say that.
answer: Except... you were gay?

question: I still am.
answer: In the years you worked at Wyant Wheeler, did you ever tell Charles Wheeler you were gay?

question: No. I didn't.
answer: Can you explain why you didn't?

question: How did that make you feel?
answer: Relieved. That I'd never told him I was gay. Very relieved.

question: Are you a good lawyer?
answer: I'm an excellent lawyer.

question: What makes you an excellent lawyer?
answer: I love the law. I know the law. I excel at practicing it. It's the only thing I've ever wanted to do.

question: What do you love about it?
answer: Well... many things. But I think the thing I love the most, is that every once in a while, not that often, but occasionally... you get to be part of justice being done. It's really quite a thrill when that happens.

question: Well... many things. But I think the thing I love the most, is that every once in a while, not that often, but occasionally... you get to be part of justice being done. It's really quite a thrill when that happens.
answer: You said earlier you aspired to be the kind of person who had "an adventurous spirit." Is that correct?

question: Something like that.
answer: Do you take risks?

question: In my work? Yes. Calculated risks. You have to.
answer: In general. Do you take risks in other areas of your life?

question: Not unnecessary ones.
answer: Have you ever been to the Apollo Cinema on Sansom Street?

question: A few times.
answer: What kind of movies do they show there?

question: Gay movies.
answer: Gay pornographic movies?

question: Yes.
answer: Do men have sex with each other in that theater?

question: Yes.
answer: How about you, Mr. Beckett? ... Have you ever had sex with someone in that theater?

question: Yes. Once. Andrew. Now what do we do?
answer: When? Approximately what year did this event take place?

question: I guess it was 1984, 85.
answer: Were you aware in 1984 or 1985 that there was a fatal disease out there, called AIDS, and that you could contract it through sexual activity?

question: It's impossible to know exactly when or how I was infected with HIV.
answer: But you were having anonymous sex in porno theaters in 1984 and 1985?

question: That happened once. People weren't talking about AIDS then, the way we are now. Or safe sex.
answer: You'd heard of AIDS in 1984, 85?

question: I'd heard of something. The gay plague, gay cancer, but... we didn't know how you could get it, or that it could kill you.
answer: Do you need a break?

question: No.
answer: While you were employed at Wyant Wheeler, you did everything you could to make sure no one knew you were an active homosexual, correct?

question: That is not correct. I never lied about it.
answer: Did you keep a picture of your lover on your desk?

question: No.
answer: Do other lawyers at the firm keep pictures of their spouses or fiances on their desks?

question: Some do. I didn't.
answer: As a homosexual, one is often forced to conceal one's sexuality, is that right?

question: In some situations.
answer: Isn't it true you have spent your life pretending to be something you're not, so much so that the art of concealment and dishonesty has become second nature to you?!

question: I'll withdraw it. Mr. Beckett? Were you living with Miguel Alvarez in 1984 or 1985 when you had your anonymous sexual encounter in the porn theater?
answer: Yes.

question: You could have infected him, isn't that right?
answer: Miguel has not been infected. As I said, we weren't aware of AIDS, then, or how it is spread.

question: Really?
answer: Yes.

question: You've testified the lesions on your face were visible to the people you worked with, correct?
answer: That's right.

question: And it's your contention, that when the partners were made aware of the lesions, they jumped to the conclusion you had AIDS and fired you.
answer: Absolutely.

question: Do you have any lesions on your face at this time?
answer: One. Here, in front of my ear.

question: Remembering you are under oath, answering truthfully, can you see the lesion on your face, in this mirror, three feet away? Answering truthfully.
answer: By the time I was fired, there were four lesions on my face, much bigger...

question: Answer the question, please.
answer: No. I can't really see it.

question: If you feel differently, Bob, you should say so, when you're called to the stand. After all, this isn't a conspiracy.
answer: Why did you recruit Andrew Beckett to your firm?

question: If you're the owner of a major league ball club, you recruit the hot rookie. And Andy was tremendously promising as a young attorney. That's why we went after him, that's why we hired him, and that's why we stuck with him, year after year... waiting for the promise to be fulfilled. But it never was.
answer: You kept giving him another chance?

question: Of course we did. When you've groomed someone they way we groomed Andy, nurturing him, lavishing all kinds of special treatment on him... you've made quite an investment. We were waiting for his promise to kick in, and deliver. But, ultimately, we could no longer ignore the gap between the promise and the reality... This is one of the saddest times in my life. To sit in this court, testifying to Andy's ultimate failure to make the grade. To discover that he is one of those people who wants to benefit by the system, but doesn't want to play by the system's rules. To think you know someone, only to find out... you don't know them at all. It's heartbreaking.
answer: Thank you. That's all for now, Your Honor.

question: What do you call a thousand lawyers chained together at the bottom of the ocean?
answer: What?

question: A good start. Excellent work, Joe. I thank you.
answer: It was good working with you, Andrew. You're welcome. Hey. Shouldn't you put that thing back on? I better get home. Lisa and I are having some friends over.

question: Sure thing.
answer: I'll see you, Beckett.

question: Thanks for coming by.
answer: You bet. We'll see you later. He's looking good. I wouldn't be surprised if he gets out of here soon.

question: You bet. We'll see you later. He's looking good. I wouldn't be surprised if he gets out of here soon.
answer: We just want to get him home. Thanks for stopping by, Joe.

question: Night.
answer: He's tired. He ought to sleep.
